review: Zoloft (sertraline):I had a mental breakdown, which I attribute either to late onset OCD or my OCD rearing its head. I couldn’t stop thinking and believing I had cheated on a homework in university 5 years ago, and wanted to get myself expelled from university. I had multiple people including a professor and academic advisor tell me it wasn’t cheating but I couldn’t stop thinking this. I had panic attacks daily until I went on Zoloft. I started on 25 mg of Zoloft and then went to 50 mg. Now if those obsessive thoughts start crawling into my mind, I can just brush them away. This medication probably saved my life, because I was getting to the point of considering suicide. I had zero side effects with this drug.

I have pure ocd and Agoraphobia. I was actually prescribed sertraline just for my panic disorder because my doctor doesn’t know about my OCD. I was prescribed 50mg for 4 weeks and I've been on 100mg for 2 weeks. The first night was awful, my anxiety went through the roof and I was convinced that I was never going to recover. I woke up the next day certain that I was gonna stop taking sertraline but I decided to keep going. After about 2 weeks i noticed a slight improvement and I noticed my thoughts weren’t causing as much anxiety and I could kind of just brush them off. After 6 weeks my OCD is so much better, if I have a distressing thought I usually just forget about it and move on. As for my Agoraphobia, I have hardly been out to know if it works for that but I’m sure if I start going out more it will be easier. I’m still waiting for the full effects of sertraline to kick in but I've heard it it can take 2-3 months.

I took sertraline for many symptoms. However, one reason I wanted to take it was my OCD of constantly checking things, especially in the evening. Unfortunately, I have to say that sertraline did not improve the conditions. I do want to mention that I noticed a decrease in panic attacks, though!I simply share this in case someone I wondering why sertraline does not seem to have the desired effect. I similarly upped the dosage, without success. (Weirdly enough, after discontinued medication, my OCD even got a slight bit better. I have no idea why. I hope this helps someone out there.)
Nice drug, first 4 days I have insomnia and anxiety but they goAfter 6-8 Days I feel more relaxedI will update.

I had a baby 4 months ago. Had a horrible Postpartum experience and started experiencing OCD thoughts/depression/anxiety. The whole postpartum depression experience. Used for Pure OCD/intrusive thoughts. Doctor suggested going up to the max of 200mg. Personally didn't experience any side effects as slowly went up from 50mg for 2 weeks, 100mg for 2 weeks, 150mg for 2 weeks and then finally the 200mg. When used alongside daily exercise and therapeutic techniques; (don’t judge thoughts no matter what they are,  if you want to think about them less actually think about them more). my condition greatly improved over the course of a year after being in a really dark place. Not a miracle cure alone but for me it greatly helped combined with other life improvements to return to a sense of normality. Didn't get rid of the thoughts, it just made me not care as much about them when I had them; breaking the anxiety loop. Ask doctor to give this medication a try. You can get your life back on track
Serataline my god.  I have depression +OCD+social anxiety. I have taken so many medicines with no results. But now with  sertraline I am happy

Zoloft (sertraline):Pure O, absolutely unstoppable tides of intrusive thoughts and ideas that would cause me to obsess over my health, checking constantly to make sure I wasn't developing or coming down with XYZ disease, mental or physical, you name it. The anxiety it would induce was so bad my psychiatrist first prescribed me xanax up to 3 times a day along with 50mg sertraline. I would say it took me a full month to feel better with it, which sucks because it meant dealing with the obsessions a full month, but once they kicked in: wow. I didn't even notice 3 months had passed without another anxious break or pure O flareup. Obviously ERP was also a huge help but I don't think I would've been able to beat OCD without it. So yeah, the only con I'd say is the time it takes for it to really kick in, a quick search shows the median being around 2-3 weeks for most people. I think my pure O being related to health caused me to worry constantly and check for side effects which might have delayed it a bit.

I've been on 50mg of sertraline for around 2 months. For the first few weeks of sertraline I felt a little dizzy and my anxiety definitely felt worse for a week or two. By around the 4th week I had kind of given up. Despite not really having any side effects, I still had all my OCD symptoms. Week 4 was especially bad, I had panic attacks every day and felt completely hopeless. But by week 5, I felt like a new person. My intrusive thoughts used to be constant and so distressing. But now I have the thoughts maybe three times a day, and I am able to dismiss them completely. Next time I see my doctor I might ask for a dosage increase as I think that I could benefit from a little more sertraline. Overall, sertraline has changed my life. It has taken me from panic attacks daily, to not being able to remember the last time I had one. Of course this is just my experience but if anybody is reading this and considering taking sertraline- I highly highly recommend that you take it. You've got this!

Zoloft has changed my life. I was diagnosed with OCD & Generalized Anxiety a little over a year ago when I entered a 6 month long mental health episode. I had been having intrusive thoughts for years & I didn’t know what they were, I just thought something was wrong with me. I struggled with (Homosexual OCD) the most. My brain convinced me that I was transgender & in denial. I felt so much shame & I wish I had gotten help sooner because it would have saved me a year of my life. I have been taking  Zoloft for almost a year now. I was very hesitant about starting antidepressants because I was scared they would make me suicidal. I tried multiple different meds ‘til I fell upon Zoloft. My initial dose was 50mg & I slowly increased to 150mg. I mean it when I say I could not live w/o this medication. I could cry about how much Zoloft has saved me, I finally feel like myself & I didn’t think that would happen again.
Constant repetitive thoughts gone within 48 hours. 2 weeks on they are slowly creeping back.

Sertraline keeps me stable. I know if I miss a dose as my anxiety is higher and my OCD is worse. It isn't a cure by any means but it does tip the scales in my favour and mean that I am much more likely to be able to use my coping strategies.

39F I suffer from mild depression. My two BIG troubles are PTSD and OCD.  I have been on Sertraline for almost three years. Started at 50mg and currently take 200mg with buspirone 2x daily. I had debilitating side effects for a full three months! The only reason I continued with the meds was because my boyfriend begged me to not stop. My quality of life was poor.  If you live or have lived with a person who is afflicted with OCD you too have a poor quality of life. After the side effects subsided I felt a feeling I had not felt in almost 15 years, quietness. Also my PTSD was not as severe but persistent. Each time my dose increased was because I could feel my inner demons peeking out from behind the curtain for longer periods of time each time they showed themselves. Each dose increase put those demons back in hiding.  I noticed that at 100mg my PTSD started to improve drastically! My PTSD made day to day life almost as difficult as my OCD.  I am no longer jumpy or spooked by triggers.

Coming up to week 8 on sertraline now and told myself I would write one of these if I ever started feeling better to help anyone desperately looking for some help like I was. It took me a good 5/6 weeks to start feeling the benefits, but I feel I am gradually improving week by week now. The first month or so of side effects weren’t the best, but this won’t be the case for everyone, and I did survive. So make sure you persevere because it is worth it! I still feel I could be better, so may up my dosage now I’ve levelled out, but I am still a far cry from the hole I was in prior to taking it. So give it a try and be kind to yourself. You get no extra credit in life for suffering

I suffered from Anxiety/Panic Attacks and OCD for 2 years before I decided to try medication. I tried therapy and self-help methods first. These helped but I found that I started spiralling every 3 months or so.I started sertraline. It took me a couple of months to feel like I was on the right path. Add an extra month on top of that until I found the right dosage for me. It is a long journey but wow... I could live again. I stopped waking up in the morning filled with dread. I stopped getting lost in thought. The worried voice in my head got quieter and quieter with every dosage increase I did.I was terrified to start taking sertraline. I avoided it as long as possible because I thought that if I didn't need it then I was still winning. Nothing good comes from suffering. If you were like me you would have read these reviews 10 times over while hesitating to start. Just take the pill.

Zoloft (sertraline):I've come to the realization over the past year that all my life I've struggled with OCD. Intrusive thoughts and obsessive behaviors have just been something I've grown to accept without knowing it. Prozac made me way too anxious and I gave up and thought I just wasn't meant for SSRIs. I was prescribed Zoloft a few months ago and it was the perfect fit. It took a while for me to find my perfect dose (150mg), but now I am a completely different person. Of course prescription meds are only one part of the equation (in addition to diet, exercise, therapy, etc) but this was a miracle. I'm writing this to say to anyone who is curious about medication for OCD or anyone who is struggling in general, there is hope and if you are patient you will see the light and find something that works. Give it time, it took me over a month to get it just right, but it was so worth it!

I’m a college student, taking half of one pill per day, I’ve been taking the drug for close to two months. The first two weeks I felt absolutely terrible considered stopping the medication but I pushed through it, heard that was common. Absolutely worth it, because after that it started to do its job. This is the first SSRI I’ve ever taken so I don’t have any comparisons but I haven’t felt anxious in a couple of weeks at all. I still have the obsessive thoughts, but not the anxiety or the compulsions that came with it. I can finally get my work done. This has been truly a great drug however I’m now experiencing occasional derealisation, more frequently than I had before the medication but I’m not sure if it is actually because of the medication or something else. I still am happy with the results so I can’t be too upset about that. I can function and that’s what matters to me.

Zoloft (sertraline):I have had a life-long anxiety disorder coupled with moderate OCD. A couple of years ago, I spiraled and became worse. The tipping point was dealing with mild DP/DR due to excessive anxiety. I avoided dealing with my anxiety head-on especially, as I didn't want to get on medication. Finally, I came around to it earlier this year. I titrated up over 2 months from 25mg to 100mg, which I'm currently on.Like many comments have indicated, it takes time, and you could need up until 100mg dose to feel better. Some of my early side-effects included mild insomnia, loss of appetite, and blurred vision. In retrospect, I would have gone on this medication sooner. You don't have much to lose if you're desperate. It could give you your life back. It has for me.

I decided that after reading these messages for over two years in an attempt to reassure myself I would pass it forward. I started taking Zoloft/Sertraline in May 2021 for OCD. I have noticed improvements. Yes, I occasionally still have intrusive thoughts, however they’re much easier to disregard and move on from. I know that might sound discouraging, but it is about 60-75% better. I have been in therapy for my sudden OCD onset since 2019; ERP based, mindfulness based and all OCD specialists. Therapy is the answer to recovery, but after two years without significant improvement I agreed to take medication. I really did believe that I could therapy my OCD away, but I decided on quality of life over my judgements about medications. I’m happier now and more at peace. I don’t have any side effects besides some mild easy bruising. Choose your mental health over everything, you’re worth recovery and you’re worth feeling better.

I have tried many meds like fluoxetine, paroxetine, aripiprazole and even anafranil for SEVERE OCD. I was hopeless about medications because they helped little with my symptoms. My ocd is related with social anxiety. Finally my GP prescribed me sertraline and after 1 month I see there is a light. Now I’m not completely symptom free but the destructive thoughts are not disturbing my mind anymore. At the first week of sertraline my anxiety got worse than before. Give it 4-6 weeks for all meds and try them until you find the right one for your body. Anafranil is a gold standard for OCD but it didn’t work for me.

Zoloft (sertraline):It has taken me 2 years to have the courage to write this post. I was incredibly desperate to find help for significant OCD (scrupulosity form mostly, among others) and at my worst was desperately combing this page looking and hoping for answers. It was terrifying. I had indications of OCD throughout my life but had some triggers 2 years ago that left me spiralling. I was very afraid to take a high dose of Zoloft and should have increased much faster. My first therapist did not get it. I then found someone on the OCD foundation website who was a godsend. The combination of working with her on ERP and 100 mg Zoloft has me happier than I’ve ever been. It took about 4 months to see a significant difference. I have virtually no side effects. Zoloft got me out of the thick of it, but my therapist brought me back to my best self. Overcoming Intrusive Thoughts was also a great read. Please know it’s a tough road but it’s worth it and you are not alone. You can get through this.

I have been diagnosed with OCD prior to the pandemic and started taking Zoloft to aid psychotherapy sessions. Absolutely 0 side effects except delayed ejaculation the first weeks and have been on it for 2 years without any problem.I finally feel like myself again and can focus more, enjoy life and see things how they were. Sometimes I still have intrusive thoughts but they do not bother me the same way anymore!

I had NO ANXIETY. ALMOST ZERO INTRUSIVE THOUGHTS. I remember feeling so relieved!! I felt alive again. On 50mg right now, I have bad moments but I’m overall fine. TRY IT!!!!

This medication has significantly changed my life. Up until my 30s, I suffered immensely. I have battled severe anxiety and OCD since I was a child. I tried various medications and natural remedies without gaining the desired therapeutic effect. I finally went on Sertraline as I was at the point of seeking psychiatric help. This medication is a blessing. I wish I had started this medication when I was younger. I now have    a great quality of life! There is help for you. God bless you.

Zoloft (sertraline):I started Zoloft after a period of stress led to me having a mental breakdown that led to weeks of crippling existential angst and depression. The things that plagued my mind just disappeared and didn’t matter anymore. I felt myself again. This drug allowed me to save my life

Zoloft (sertraline):I read these reviews over and over again to calm myself with what I was going through. Although thinking back it might of been obsessive. Zoloft (sertraline):I started on Zoloft a few months ago and I can’t stop getting what I like to call thinking attacks because I just get stuck in this infinite loop of am I real? What is real? Why does everything do everything it does? I believe I developed existential OCD due to Zoloft

Zoloft (sertraline):I have OCD, and honestly, this medication has given me my life back. This was the second med I took; lexapro was horrible for me. I have been taking Zoloft for 3.5 months. I was also seeing an OCD therapist through NOCD. You will definitely see better, faster results if you use this medication in conjunction with therapy. God bless everyone, I know OCD can be tormenting but you have GOT THIS!!!

I have suffered with OCD for nearly 4 years. I found 200mg Sertraline to be the most effective drug. I had been prescribed other drugs but none as good. OCD is a horrible illness rooted in anxiety. Sertraline definitely helped lower my anxiety & thus make best use of CBT. For 3 years I despaired of ever getting better but the last year has been a turning point. For me once I had the right drug to reduce the anxiety I found it is possible to improve. I got to the point where it was a choice to either carry out a compulsion & knowing how bad I would feel afterwards that I had failed to stop yet again compared to not undertaking a compulsion & sitting with the anxiety until it reduced. Improving was not all plain sailing but I was determined to carry on reaching goals I never thought possible. I post this comment to give hope to other sufferers. I don't know if I will ever be free of OCD but am now at a point where it does not dominate - something I prayed for but thought would never happen.

I have taken this medication for over 2 years and it has worked well for me. It has no worse side effects than the other SSRIs I've taken.

sertraline is the best SSRI for obsessive compulsive disorder

I switched from citalopram to 50mg sertraline 7 weeks ago and upped my dose to 100mg 4 weeks ago. I suffer from anxiety and OCD, was having really horrid intrusive thoughts. Started sertraline Oct 2020 my dose was 50mg for 2 weeks then onto 100mg. After 2.5 weeks I had a good spell of 5 days which quickly deteriorated into awful anxiety and depression. I tried on Pregablin which made me feel suicidal. I then increased to 150mg but I have never felt so frightened in my life. Suicidal ideation, awful anxiety and depression. I felt hopeless. Between Christmas and new year I decided to cut down to 25mg and within a week it is night and day. I have returned to work. I am walking and jogging every day whereas before I could hardly get off the sofa. The medics see a dose not working and the default position is to increase it. The increases came close to finishing me off. I know 150mg has turned people’s lives around but for me it was horrendous. Please listen to your body. It is so difficult when meds don’t work but trust your instincts. I hope this can help someone as I was in a very dark place on the wrong dose of this medication but now I feel positive I have found a balance.

I was recently diagnosed with OCD and a psychiatrist recommended I take Zoloft. I barely get any now and if I want to decide not to think about them, I simply don’t. That’s something I could never dream of doing before taking this medicine. One thing I noticed, however, is that I have more compulsions still but with quick emotions attached rather than complex.
